docs.lead_paragraph: The Pataki administration today threatened to allow the state's system of setting hospital rates to expire on July 1, potentially throwing the health care industry into chaos, if the Legislature does not agree to deregulate the industry by then. Health care officials said that the move would force many hospitals, particularly those serving poor communities, to roll back vital services or even close by the end of the year.

headline.main: Pataki Issues An Ultimatum On Hospitals

docs.snippet: The Pataki administration today threatened to allow the state's system of setting hospital rates to expire on July 1, potentially throwing the health care industry into chaos, if the Legislature does not agree to deregulate the industry by then.     ...

docs.lead_paragraph: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani distanced himself yesterday from a report by an advisory board he appointed, which proposed that the city levy a surcharge on hospital fees and insurance premiums to subsidize health insurance for those without it. Calling the recommendations a "very important beginning" in solving the problem of how to finance health care for the uninsured, the Mayor nevertheless said he was not ready to endorse them.

headline.main: Mayor Keeps His Distance From New Insurance Plan

docs.snippet: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani distanced himself yesterday from a report by an advisory board he appointed, which proposed that the city levy a surcharge on hospital fees and insurance premiums to subsidize health insurance for those without it.        ...

docs.lead_paragraph: A mayoral panel's recommendation that medical care for the indigent be paid by a surcharge on hospital fees and insurance premiums drew a cautious response from Mayor Giuliani, who called the proposal a "beginning" to solving the problem of health care for the uninsured. His comments came as analysts expressed skepticism about the financing proposals and concerns about whether the plan would pass muster among legislators and health care providers.

headline.main: Giuliani Shows Caution On New Health Plan

docs.lead_paragraph: Former Mayor John V. Lindsay, in declining health, has been appointed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to two city posts to make him eligible for municipal health insurance coverage and eventually, perhaps, to qualify him for a pension. In recent years, strokes and Parkinson's disease have been described as eroding Mr. Lindsay's once-athletic physique and taking a severe toll on his finances.

headline.main: Ailing Lindsay Is Given Posts To Get City Health Insurance

docs.lead_paragraph: With new ways of controlling the cost of mental health care, some experts say, it may now be feasible for Congress to require insurance coverage for mental illness on a par with coverage for other illnesses. The Senate recently voted to require equivalent coverage for mental and physical illnesses, a radical change from current practice. Most health plans now set lower limits on hospital days and doctors' visits, or require patients to pay a larger share of the bill, for treatment of mental illness.

headline.main: Wider Mental Health Policies Seen as Feasible Requirement

docs.lead_paragraph: A mayoral advisory panel has recommended that New York City fundamentally change the way it pays for health care for the indigent, proposing that the government subsidize insurance for the uninsured rather than maintain the current system of subsidizing hospitals that treat the poor. The seven-member panel, whose report is scheduled for release today, said its proposals were intended to "promote and encourage the use of primary and preventive care and minimize overreliance on an expensive hospital system."

headline.main: PANEL URGES SHIFT IN HOW NEW YORK PAYS HEALTH BILLS
